results.title: Evonne Goolagong Cawley crowns Ash Barty Australian Open champion
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @AustralianOpen Twitter post
results.brief_description: Ngarigo woman and world number one in women’s singles tennis, Ash Barty, accepts the Daphne Akhurst Memorial Cup after a two-set victory in her Australian Open finals match against Danielle Collins. The trophy was bestowed on her by former world number one, Wiradjuri tennis legend Evonne Goolagong Cawley, who was crowned women’s singles champion at the Australian Open four years running, from 1974-77.
results.title_for_label: Evonne Goolagong Cawley crowns champion Ash Barty at the Australian Open
results.description: Ngarigo woman and women’s tennis world number one Ash Barty accepts the Daphne Akhurst Memorial Cup after a two-set victory in the Australian Open final against Danielle Collins. The trophy was bestowed on her by former world number one, Wiradjuri tennis legend Evonne Goolagong Cawley, who was crowned women’s singles champion at the Australian Open four years running, from 1974-77.
description_for_label: Ngarigo woman and women’s tennis world number one Ash Barty accepts the Daphne Akhurst Memorial Cup after a two-set victory in the Australian Open final against Danielle Collins. The trophy was bestowed on her by former world number one, Wiradjuri tennis legend Evonne Goolagong Cawley, who was crowned women’s singles champion at the Australian Open four years running, from 1974-77.

results.title: Aussie Ashes win
results.brief_description: After crushing the Brits with a 4-0 sweep in the 2021 Ashes series, the Aussie team celebrated with the customary champagne popping. But not everyone could join in. Skipper Pat Cummins told the players to put down the bottles so Usman Khawaja, who is Muslim and doesn’t drink alcohol, could rejoin. Khawaja killed it in the fourth test, where he made a century in both innings he played. He tweeted the footage, heralding the moment as a step ‘in the right direction’ towards better inclusivity, acknowledging that there’s more work to be done to address racism in Australian sport.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

After crushing the Brits with a 4-0 sweep in the 2021 Ashes series, the Aussie team celebrated with the customary champagne popping. But not everyone could join in. Usman Khawaja was integral throughout the series, particularly in the fourth test when he made a century in both innings, but as a Muslim doesn’t drink alcohol. Skipper Pat Cummins told the players to put down the bottles so that he could rejoin the festivities. Khawaja retweeted the footage, heralding the moment as a step ‘in the right direction’ towards better inclusivity, subtly acknowledging that there’s more work to be done to address racism in Australian sport.

Read Osman Faruqi’s analysis of the moment on they Sydney Morning Herald.
description_for_label: After crushing the Brits with a 4-0 sweep in the 2021 Ashes series, the Aussie team celebrated with the customary champagne popping. But not everyone could join in. Usman Khawaja was integral throughout the series, particularly in the fourth test when he made a century in both innings, but as a Muslim doesn’t drink alcohol. Skipper Pat Cummins told the players to put down the bottles so that he could rejoin the festivities. Khawaja retweeted the footage, heralding the moment as a step ‘in the right direction’ towards better inclusivity, subtly acknowledging that there’s more work to be done to address racism in Australian sport.

results.title: Molly Mae faces backlash
results.brief_description: Influencer and former Love Island contestant, Molly- Mae Hague, faces backlash after a clip of her talking about her work ethic went viral. During a podcast interview she implied that poverty is linked to laziness, claiming that “everyone has the same 24 hours”.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Influencer and former Love Island contestant, Molly- Mae Hague, faced backlash after a clip of her talking about her work ethic went viral. During a podcast interview she implied that poverty is linked to laziness, claiming that “everyone has the same 24 hours”.

At a moment when people are suffering the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic, including the inability to work because of lockdowns and quarantine orders (not to mention inequality growing globally), the comment was more than a little tone deaf.

As the Mirror reports: “Many others fumed over the fact that Molly-Mae claims she works hard when she was appointed Creative Director of Pretty Little Thing which is a company that is owned by Boo Hoo Group – who got busted in 2020 for ‘modern day slavery’ for paying employees just £3.50 per hour.”

Check out the original story on ScreenShotHQ’s Instagram for more details and reactions.
description_for_label:
Influencer and former Love Island contestant, Molly- Mae Hague, faced backlash after a clip of her talking about her work ethic went viral. During a podcast interview she implied that poverty is linked to laziness, claiming that “everyone has the same 24 hours”.

At a moment when people are suffering the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic, including the inability to work because of lockdowns and quarantine orders (not to mention inequality growing globally), the comment was more than a little tone deaf.

results.title: Run for our rights
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @aiww's instagram feed
results.brief_description: Chinese artist Ai Wei Wei is campaigning against threats to journalistic free speech by encouraging others to post videos of themselves “running for our rights”. Australian journalist Julian Assange gave Ai Wei Wei a treadmill he used while living at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London. Assange faces potential extradition and prison in America for publishing US government documents on Wikileaks.
results.description:

Assange faces potential extradition and prison in America for publishing US government documents on Wikileaks.

results.title: South Dakota "Dash for Cash"
results.brief_description: You’d be forgiven for mistaking this for a scene out of Squid Game, but unfortunately it’s not a hit dystopian TV show – it’s the Sioux Falls Stampede ice hockey team’s inaugural “Dash for Cash”, which saw local teachers compete for money to buy school supplies.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

You’d be forgiven for mistaking this for a scene out of Squid Game, but unfortunately it’s not a dystopian TV show where contestants risk their lives in murderous games for cash prizes – it’s the Sioux Falls Stampede ice hockey team’s inaugural “Dash for Cash”. The people scrambling for $5000 worth of one-dollar bills, while the stadium cheers, are local teachers, who intend to use the money for school supplies. After the footage went viral on social media, it started a seemingly much-needed debate about school funding in America, which saw many teachers reveal that they routinely used their own money to buy classroom necessities, as well as raised questions of how we ended up in a society where desperation is turned into spectacle.

The footage was seen as particularly callous towards South Dakota teachers, who according to CBS News, earn the lowest salary in their profession in America.

“While the Dash for the Cash may have been well-intentioned, it only underscores the fact that educators don’t have the resources necessary to meet the needs of their students,” Loren Paul, president of South Dakota’s teacher union, said in a statement to CBS MoneyWatch. “As a state, we shouldn’t be forcing teachers to wrestle with one another to get the money they need to fund their classrooms.”

At a time when inequality is growing globally and teachers have born the brunt of teaching remotely during the Covid-19 pandemic, more than a few users found the event tasteless at best and at worst, just another sign we’re living in the worst timeline. In response to the backlash, the Sioux Falls Stampede, and CU Mortgage Direct, who fronted the cash, released a statement apologising, saying: “we can see how it appears to be degrading and insulting towards the participating teachers and the teaching profession as a whole.”

The two organisations have since donated a further $15,000 USD to the participants.
description_for_label: You’d be forgiven for mistaking this for a scene out of Squid Game, but unfortunately it’s not a hit dystopian TV show – it’s the Sioux Falls Stampede ice hockey team’s inaugural “Dash for Cash”. The people scrambling for the one-dollar bills (there’s $5000 worth on the ice) while the stadium cheers them on are local teachers, who are going to use the money for school supplies. After the event went viral on social media, it started a debate about funding for schools in America, leading to an additional $500 USD being donated to participants by the event organisers.

results.title: Scottsman drops his turkey
results.brief_description: We’re on the slippery slope towards Christmas, that hectic time of year when we rush around desperately trying to get everything done. Come Christmas dinner we can relax a bit, the work is done and we get to enjoy the fruits of our labours, unless you’re this guy…

results.title: Questions asked following acquittal of Kyle Rittenhouse
results.brief_description: Political commentator Van Jones asks if we are experiencing a new era of vigilante behavior, following the acquittal of Kyle Rittenhouse. This month, a jury found Rittenhouse not guilty on all charges related to the fatal shooting of two people at an anti-racism protest in Kenosha, Wisconsin. The case has reignited debate over racial justice and gun rights.

The case has reignited debate over racial justice and gun rights.

results.title: Trans model and advocate AJ Clementine walks her first show at Melbourne Fashion Week
results.brief_description: On Monday, trans model and advocate AJ Clementine walked her first Melbourne Fashion Week show - a perfect start to Transgender Awareness Week, which runs 13-19 November.
results.title_for_label: Celebrating trans models at Melbourne Fashion Week
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.


On Monday 15 November, trans model and advocate AJ Clementine walked her first Melbourne Fashion Week show – a perfect start to Transgender Awareness Week, which runs 13-19 November.

results.title: Eye of fire
results.brief_description: A gas leak in an underwater pipeline caused an oceanic fireball dubbed ‘The Eye of Fire’ in the Gulf of Mexico. The state owned company is investigating the causes.

constellations_other.name: Deep blue
constellations_other.description: Go deep on an exploration of real world oceans and those rendered by pixels and creatures made from plastics.

results.title_for_label: ‘Eye of fire’ in the Gulf of Mexico
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

In horrific scenes that seemed more like footage from an action movie than the real world, the ocean was literally on fire on 3 July 2021 in the Gulf of Mexico. The huge fireball blazing across the sea surface was caused by a gas leak from an underwater pipeline, which social media users dubbed ‘the eye of fire’. The video was shared across the internet as further evidence of the environmental tolls of capitalism and the irresponsibility of fossil fuel companies plundering natural resources and producing unnatural results.
description_for_label:
This responsive display presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

In astonishing scenes, the ocean was literally on fire on 3 July 2021 in the Gulf of Mexico. The fireball blazing across the sea surface, dubbed the ‘eye of fire’ by social media users, was caused by an underwater gas leak from a pipeline. The video spread across the internet as further evidence of fossil fuel companies plundering natural resources and producing unnatural results.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Shadowrun for SNES
results.creator_credit: Data East USA and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cartidge videogame. Cartridge, reference sheet and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
In the early 1990s, Nintendo didn’t allow sex, drugs and alcohol to appear on its consoles. Games also couldn’t show blood or graphic violence. This presented a challenge for Australian developers Beam Software, who were turning the gritty pen-and-paper roleplaying game Shadowrun into a future classic.

So while the protagonist Jake can only order a ‘warm glass of milk’ in a sleazy ‘club’ (‘bars’ weren’t allowed), Beam still managed to deliver a dark neo-noir story true to the original RPG’s seedy cyberpunk world. That world was realised through Beam’s technical innovations, including character masking, an isometric view and a keyword dialogue system previously only seen on PCs.

But it was lead designer Pauli Kidd’s wry and atmospheric writing that ensured the beloved tabletop RPG became one of the most critically acclaimed games of the 1990s.

So while the protagonist Jake can only order a ‘warm glass of milk’ in a sleazy ‘club’ (‘bars’ weren’t allowed), Beam still managed to deliver a dark neo-noir story true to the original RPG’s seedy cyberpunk world. That world was realised through Beam’s technical innovations, including character masking, an isometric view and a keyword dialogue system previously only seen on PCs.

But it was lead designer Pauli Kidd’s wry and atmospheric writing that ensured the beloved tabletop RPG became one of the most critically acclaimed games of the 1990s.

This presented a challenge for Australian developers Beam Software, who were turning the gritty pen-and-paper roleplaying game Shadowrun into a future classic.
